Best Bet

Marking the anniversaries of the Wannsee Conference, Jan. 20, 1942, and the liberation of Auschwitz, Jan. 27, 1945, the Cinema Arts Center, on Park Avenue in Huntington, has put together ''Refocusing the Holocaust: New Stories, New Dimensions.''

The program, a series of films and discussions, includes a showing of the new movie ''The Pianist,'' directed by Roman Polanski. The film is accompanied by talks by Dr. Jud Newborn, a Holocaust scholar, and Annie Bloomberg, a survivor, at 11 a.m. today, and at 7 p.m. on Saturday, by Avraham Sternklar, a composer who was in the United States Army during World War II and guarded Nazi war criminals when they were under arrest.

Other films in the series are ''Max,'' about the relationship between a Jewish art dealer, played by John Cusack, with a young Hitler, opening on Jan. 17, and on Jan. 24, Costa-Gavras's ''Amen,'' about a German chemist whose rodent-control formula is used on humans.

At 2:30 p.m. next Sunday, Loring Mandel, a screenwriter, will appear with a showing of his film ''Conspiracy,'' a drama about the Wannsee Conference. ''They Looked Away: Why Wasn't Auschwitz Bombed'' will be shown at 7 p.m. on Jan. 14, with a talk by Stuart Erdheim, its writer-director. Information: (631) 423-7611.
Where's Your Kilt?

Ed Miller, a Scottish folk singer whose repertory runs from Robert Burns's songs to 20th-century ballads, helps Big Grey, a Celtic-music series, celebrate its 10th anniversary on Saturday with ''Auld and New Acquaintances.''

Banshee in the Kitchen, a West Coast ensemble, will be featured in the concert, which also marks the birthday of Burns. The program begins at 8 p.m. at the Searingtown-Roslyn United Methodist Church on I. U. Willets Road in Albertson. Information: (631) 321-1582.
A Turbulent Time
A concert presented by the group Ridotto focuses on ''Beethoven and Goya'' today.

With Carol Montparker, pianist, and Dennis Parker, cellist, doing the musical honors and Margaretha Maimone handling the narration, the program explores the similarities between the two artists, who were both affected by the French Revolution and war during Napoleon's domination of Europe.
The concert is at 4 p.m. at the Old First Church on Main Street in Huntington. Information: (631) 385-0373.
Clemens vs. Twain
Pitting Samuel Clemens against his alter-ego, Mark Twain, Drew Keil, a playwright, has created ''Heaven-Sent, the After-Life of Mark Twain.''

With Stephen Ryan playing Twain and Brian McKeon as Clemens, the play, which its author says ''employs their homespun wit and worldly wisdom to showcase the facts and fantasies of their singular, celebrated life,'' has its world premiere on Friday at the Spiegel Theater on Hofstra University's Hempstead campus. It will run through Jan. 26. Information: (516) 463-6644.

In Smithtown, the new Center for the Performing Arts opens ''Art'' on Friday. The comedy -- which has fun with what is, or isn't, art -- runs through Jan. 26 at the center on Main Street. Information: (631) 724-3700.
Free Choices

TODAY -- The Islip Arts Council opens its winter chamber music series at 2 p.m. at the Carriage House at Bayard Cutting Arboretum in Oakdale with Gregor Kitzis, violinist, and Mary Bopp, pianist, playing works by Bloch, Liszt and Schumann. After three more outings at the arboretum, the series moves to Fortunoff Hall on the Oakdale campus of Dowling College through February and March. Information: (631) 224-5420.

Bryan Mark Rigg, an author, begins his tour of local libraries with ''Hitler's Jewish Soldiers: The Untold Story of Nazi Racial Laws and Men of Jewish Descent in the German Military'' at 3 p.m. at the Jericho Library on Merry Lane. Information: (516) 935-6970. Other stops on his schedule are on Wednesday at 2 p.m. at the library on Broadway in Hewlett, (516) 374-1967, and at 2:30 p.m. on Thursday at the library on Old Country Road in Plainview. (516) 938-0077.
SATURDAY -- Learn about ''Maple Sugaring: From Sap to Syrup'' in a family nature program at 10 a.m. at West Hills County Park in Melville. Information: (631) 581-6908.
Jeffrey Biegel, a pianist, plays works by Beethoven, Chopin and Gershwin at 8 p.m. at the Port Washington Library on Main Street. Information: (516) 883-4400.
